formalized_text: The system shall be a single-player digital board game named "Monopoly Tycoon", developed exclusively for the Windows operating system.
original_text: To develop a high-quality, single-player digital adaptation of the classic Monopoly board game, named "Monopoly Tycoon," for the Windows platform.

formalized_text: The system shall provide a gameplay experience where a single human player competes against one or more AI-controlled opponents, rendered in a polished 3D graphical environment.
original_text: The game will pit a human player against challenging and engaging AI opponents, featuring polished 3D graphics and strict adherence to the official game rules.

formalized_text: The system's core game logic shall strictly implement and enforce the official rules of the standard U.S. Monopoly board game as published by Hasbro (2024 baseline version).
original_text: Authenticity: Replicate the standard Monopoly gameplay mechanics and rules with high fidelity.

formalized_text: The system shall implement AI opponents with tunable difficulty levels, controlled by an algorithmic decision-making process, to provide a variable challenge for the human player.
original_text: Challenge: Implement a tunable, algorithmic AI that provides a compelling experience for a human player of varying skill levels.

formalized_text: The system shall present the game from an isometric camera perspective, utilizing high-quality 3D models, textures, and visual effects to create a modern and immersive visual experience.
original_text: Visual Appeal: Deliver a modern, visually immersive experience using high-quality 3D graphics and an isometric perspective.

formalized_text: The system shall include features designed to enhance replayability, specifically: a persistent player profile with historical statistics, selectable AI difficulty levels, and a theme customization system.
original_text: Replayability: Encourage repeated playthroughs via features like a persistent player profile with statistics, variable AI difficulty, and a dynamic theme system.

formalized_text: The system shall support game sessions consisting of one human player competing against a configurable number of 1, 2, or 3 AI opponents.
original_text: Full implementation of standard Monopoly rules for one human player against 1 to 3 AI opponents.

formalized_text: The system shall explicitly exclude the following features: any form of human vs. human multiplayer, house rules or game variations, in-game purchases, any form of network connectivity, and support for non-Windows operating systems.
original_text: Out-of-Scope Features: Any form of online or local multiplayer (human vs. human). House rules or non-standard game variations. In-game purchases or microtransactions. Network connectivity for any purpose. Support for platforms other than Windows OS.

formalized_text: The application's core logic and scripting shall be developed using the .NET 8 framework.
original_text: The game shall be developed using the .NET 8 framework.

formalized_text: The application shall be compatible with and fully functional on the specified versions of the Windows operating system.
original_text: The game shall be playable on the Windows OS.

formalized_text: The system shall be developed using the Unity game engine, with all game logic and interactions implemented via C# scripting.
original_text: The game shall be developed using the Unity game engine with C# scripting to meet the 3D graphics, visual polish, and cross-component integration requirements.

formalized_text: The application shall be packaged and distributed as a standalone installer created with Inno Setup, which provides the user with options to specify the installation directory and create a desktop shortcut.
original_text: The game shall be distributed via a standalone installer package created using Inno Setup. The installation process shall be simple, requiring minimal user intervention and providing options for installation directory and desktop shortcut creation.

formalized_text: The system shall have defined minimum and recommended hardware specifications. Minimum: Win 10 (64-bit), Dual-core 2.4 GHz CPU, 4 GB RAM, DX11 GPU w/ 1 GB VRAM, 2 GB storage. Recommended: Win 11 (64-bit), Quad-core 3.0 GHz CPU, 8 GB RAM, DX12 GPU w/ 4 GB VRAM, 2 GB storage.
original_text: Minimum System Requirements: OS: Windows 10 (64-bit), Processor: Dual-core CPU @ 2.4 GHz, Memory: 4 GB RAM, Graphics: DirectX 11 compatible GPU with 1 GB VRAM, Storage: 2 GB available space. Recommended System Requirements: OS: Windows 11 (64-bit), Processor: Quad-core CPU @ 3.0 GHz, Memory: 8 GB RAM, Graphics: DirectX 12 compatible GPU with 4 GB VRAM, Storage: 2 GB available space.

formalized_text: The application must render at a sustained average of 60 frames per second (FPS) and must not drop below 45 FPS during typical gameplay scenarios when running at 1920x1080 resolution on a system that meets the recommended specifications.
original_text: The game must maintain a stable 60 frames per second (FPS), with no drops below 45 FPS, at 1920x1080 resolution under typical gameplay conditions on a system meeting the recommended hardware specifications.

formalized_text: The system shall ensure that the time elapsed from initiating a 'New Game' or 'Load Game' action from the main menu to the moment the game is playable shall not exceed 10 seconds on a system meeting the recommended specifications, including an SSD.
original_text: Asset loading times when starting a new game or loading a save file from the main menu shall not exceed 10 seconds on a system with an SSD meeting recommended specifications.

formalized_text: The system's user interface and game camera view must dynamically scale to correctly support 16:9, 16:10, and 21:9 aspect ratios, ensuring no UI elements are obscured, distorted, or rendered non-functional.
original_text: The UI and game view shall be scalable to support common aspect ratios (e.g., 16:9, 16:10, 21:9) without visual artifacts or loss of functionality.

formalized_text: The system shall implement interactive graphical elements to provide visual feedback and enhance user experience, including but not limited to: animated dice rolls, animated token movement, visual highlighting of selected properties, and visual effects for monetary transactions.
original_text: Interactive graphical elements shall be implemented to enhance user experience (e.g., animated dice, moving player tokens, property highlights, visual effects for transactions).

formalized_text: The system shall integrate the Serilog framework to handle all application logging, configured to produce structured log entries.
original_text: The game shall implement the Serilog framework for structured, configurable logging.

formalized_text: The logging system shall be configured to output logs in a structured JSON format to a local file, capturing events at specified levels: INFO for key game events, DEBUG for AI decision-making processes, and ERROR for exceptions and faults.
original_text: Logs shall capture key game events (INFO), AI decisions (DEBUG), and errors (ERROR) to a local file in a structured JSON format.

formalized_text: The system shall store all generated log files in a 'logs' subdirectory within the application's data folder, located at the standard user path `%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon/`.
original_text: The log file shall be stored in a user-accessible location (`%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon/logs`).

formalized_text: The logging system shall be configured with a rolling file policy that automatically manages log file retention. The system will retain logs for a maximum of 7 days or a total size of 50 MB, whichever limit is reached first, deleting the oldest files to stay within the configured limits.
original_text: The logging system shall use a rolling file mechanism, retaining the last 7 days of logs or a maximum of 50 MB of log files, whichever is smaller, to prevent excessive disk usage.

formalized_text: The system must ensure that no personally identifiable information (PII) is written to any log file, with the sole exception of the user-provided profile name which is permitted for debugging context.
original_text: No personally identifiable information (PII), other than the user-provided profile name, shall be written to logs.

formalized_text: In the event of an unhandled exception, the system shall display a modal error dialog to the user. This dialog must: 1) Inform the user that an error occurred, 2) Provide a unique error identifier, and 3) Instruct the user on how to find the log files. The displayed error identifier must directly correlate to a specific entry in the error log.
original_text: The game shall feature a user-friendly error dialog for unhandled exceptions. This dialog will inform the user of the error, provide a unique error ID that correlates to a specific log entry, and give instructions on how to locate the log file for support purposes.

formalized_text: The project's development shall adhere to the following technical standards: 1) All source code must be managed in a Git version control repository. 2) The primary Integrated Development Environment (IDE) shall be Visual Studio 2022. 3) All C# code must conform to the Microsoft C# Coding Conventions.
original_text: The project source code shall be managed using the Git version control system. Development shall be conducted using Visual Studio 2022. All C# code shall adhere to the Microsoft C# Coding Conventions.

formalized_text: The system's core logic, including the rule engine, economic model, and AI decision stubs, shall be accompanied by a suite of unit tests written using the NUnit framework, achieving a minimum of 70% code coverage for these components.
original_text: The core game logic (rule engine, economic model, AI decision stubs) shall have a minimum of 70% unit test coverage using the NUnit framework.

formalized_text: The system shall include integration tests that validate key end-to-end workflows. At a minimum, these tests must cover: 1) Saving a game state and successfully loading it back, 2) The complete trade negotiation sequence between two players, and 3) The process of a player going bankrupt and their assets being correctly transferred.
original_text: Key end-to-end workflows, including the save/load process, trade negotiation sequences, and the bankruptcy-to-asset-transfer cycle, shall be covered by integration tests.

formalized_text: A curated collection of predefined save game files shall be created and maintained as part of the test assets. This collection must include scenarios for testing specific edge cases, such as a player near bankruptcy, a board state with a housing shortage, and complex property ownership configurations.
original_text: A suite of predefined game state files shall be created and maintained to facilitate testing of specific edge cases and complex scenarios (e.g., a game state on the verge of bankruptcy, a housing shortage scenario).

formalized_text: The system's logger shall record all key economic transactions at the INFO level. Each log entry for a transaction must be a structured object containing, at a minimum: the current turn number, the IDs of all involved players, the transaction type, and all relevant financial or property data, creating a complete audit trail.
original_text: Key economic transactions (e.g., property purchase, rent payment, trade completion, mortgage actions) must be logged at the INFO level. Each logged transaction must include the turn number, the involved player IDs, the type of transaction, and relevant values (e.g., cash amount, property IDs) to create a verifiable audit trail for debugging and analysis.

formalized_text: The system shall enforce a player count between 2 and 4 (inclusive) for any game session, which must always consist of exactly one human player and between 1 and 3 AI players.
original_text: The game shall support a total of 2 to 4 players, consisting of one human player and 1 to 3 computer-controlled (AI) opponents.

formalized_text: The system shall provide a game setup screen where the human player must be able to configure the number of AI opponents (1, 2, or 3). For each AI opponent, the player must be able to independently set its difficulty level to one of 'Easy', 'Medium', or 'Hard'.
original_text: The game setup screen shall allow the human player to configure the number of AI opponents (1, 2, or 3) and set the difficulty level (Easy, Medium, Hard) for each individual AI opponent.

formalized_text: The system shall represent each player's state using a data object (`PlayerState`) that encapsulates the following attributes: a unique `player_id`, a display `player_name`, a boolean `is_human` flag, an `ai_difficulty` enum, a `token_id`, current `cash` balance, a list of `properties_owned`, the `current_position` on the board (0-39), a count of `get_out_of_jail_cards`, a player `status` enum (e.g., Active, InJail), and `jail_turns_remaining`.
original_text: Each player, whether human or AI, shall be represented by a data object containing: player_id, player_name, is_human, ai_difficulty, token_id, cash, properties_owned, current_position, get_out_of_jail_cards, status, jail_turns_remaining.

formalized_text: The system shall manage a human player profile consisting of a user-provided display name and a system-generated, persistent, unique `profile_id`. The display name input must be validated to be between 3 and 16 characters long and must not contain special characters.
original_text: The system shall support a simple profile for the human player, which includes a display name entered by the user. This name will be used in UI elements and in the Top Score History. The system shall assign a persistent, unique profile_id for internal data tracking. The display name input field shall be validated to have a length between 3 and 16 characters and disallow special characters that could interfere with file systems or display logic.

formalized_text: The system must track and permanently store a set of historical gameplay statistics for the human player's profile. This data must be associated with the profile's unique `profile_id` and persist across game sessions.
original_text: The system shall track and persist historical gameplay statistics for the human player's profile, linked via profile_id.

formalized_text: The persisted player statistics shall include at least the following metrics: total games played, total wins, win/loss ratio, average game duration, the most profitable property (by total rent collected), total rent paid, total rent collected, total properties acquired, and the largest trade deal (by combined asset value).
original_text: This includes, at a minimum: Total games played. Total wins. Win/Loss ratio. Average game duration. Most profitable property (by total rent collected). Total rent paid and collected. Total properties acquired. Largest trade deal (by combined value).

formalized_text: The system's game setup screen shall allow the human player to select a game token from a collection of at least 8 distinct, classic options. After the player's selection, the system must automatically and randomly assign unique tokens to all AI opponents from the remaining pool.
original_text: During game setup, the human player shall be able to select their visual game piece (token) from a predefined set of at least 8 classic options (e.g., Top Hat, Car, Thimble). AI opponents will be assigned the remaining pieces automatically and randomly.

formalized_text: The system shall implement a game board that is an accurate digital representation of the standard 40-space Monopoly board, including all 28 properties (22 colored, 4 railroads, 2 utilities), 3 Chance spaces, 3 Community Chest spaces, 2 tax spaces, and the 4 corner spaces.
original_text: The game board shall accurately represent the standard 40 spaces...

formalized_text: The system shall manage game progression using a turn-based structure. The turn order shall cycle sequentially through the human player and all AI players who have not been eliminated from the game.
original_text: The game shall proceed in a turn-based manner, cycling through the human player and all active AI players.

formalized_text: The system shall structure each player's turn into a sequence of distinct phases: Pre-Turn (handling jail status), Pre-Roll Management (building, trading), Roll (dice throw), Movement (token advances), Action (effect of landing space), and Post-Roll (handling doubles or passing turn).
original_text: A turn sequence shall consist of: 1. Pre-Turn Phase... 2. Pre-Roll Management Phase... 3. Roll Phase... 4. Movement Phase... 5. Action Phase... 6. Post-Roll Phase...

formalized_text: During the human player's Pre-Roll Management phase, the system shall provide access to the property management UI (for building, trading, mortgaging) and must wait for an explicit user action (e.g., clicking a 'Roll Dice' button) before proceeding to the Roll Phase.
original_text: Human Player: The game shall present the UI for property management (building, trading, mortgaging) and wait for the player to signal they are ready to roll.

formalized_text: When the human player's turn results in an action that requires a decision (e.g., buying an unowned property, responding to a trade), the system must halt game progression and display a modal UI prompt presenting the available choices, waiting for the user's input before continuing.
original_text: Human Player: If the action requires a decision (e.g., buying a property), the game shall display a UI prompt and wait for user input.

formalized_text: The system shall manage the entire state of an active game within a single, comprehensive `GameState` object. This object must contain all data required to fully restore a game, including: a list of all `PlayerState` objects, the ownership and building level of all properties, the number of available houses and hotels in the bank, the precise order of the Chance and Community Chest card decks, and game metadata such as the current turn number and active player.
original_text: The system shall maintain a comprehensive `GameState` object, which encapsulates the entire state of a match and is the primary subject of the save/load functionality. This object shall include: A list of all `PlayerState` objects. `board_state`: Ownership and development level (houses/hotel) of all properties. `bank_state`: Number of houses and hotels remaining in the bank. `deck_states`: The current order of cards in the Chance and Community Chest decks, including the discard pile. `game_metadata`: Current turn number, active player ID, and game session timestamp.

formalized_text: The system shall simulate dice rolls by generating two independent random integers between 1 and 6. The random number generation must use a cryptographically secure algorithm to ensure unpredictability and fairness.
original_text: The game shall simulate the rolling of two six-sided dice using a cryptographically secure random number generator to ensure fairness.

formalized_text: The system must correctly implement the doubles rule: 1) If a player rolls doubles, they take another turn after completing their first. 2) If a player rolls doubles three consecutive times in a single turn, their turn ends immediately, and they are sent directly to Jail.
original_text: The rule for rolling doubles (allowing an extra turn) and the consequence of rolling three consecutive doubles (going to Jail) shall be implemented.

formalized_text: The system shall automatically award a player $200 from the Bank each time their token lands on or passes over the 'Go' space.
original_text: Go: Players passing or landing on 'Go' shall collect $200 from the Bank.

formalized_text: The system shall implement all rules related to Jail. A player must be sent to Jail if they land on 'Go to Jail', draw the corresponding card, or roll three consecutive doubles. While in Jail, a player must be given the options to pay a $50 fine or use a 'Get Out of Jail Free' card. On their turn, they may attempt to roll doubles. If they fail to roll doubles for three consecutive turns in Jail, they must automatically pay the $50 fine and move the sum of their third roll.
original_text: Jail: Players go to Jail by landing on 'Go to Jail', drawing a 'Go to Jail' card, or rolling three consecutive doubles. Players can get out by paying a $50 fine, using a 'Get Out of Jail Free' card, or rolling doubles on one of their next three turns. If they fail to roll doubles on the third turn, they must pay the $50 fine.

formalized_text: The system shall ensure that landing on the 'Free Parking' space results in no action or effect on the player's state or the game state.
original_text: Free Parking: Landing on Free Parking shall have no effect on the player.

formalized_text: The system shall manage the Chance and Community Chest decks. When a player lands on a corresponding space, the system must draw the top card from the appropriate deck, automatically execute its instruction, and then place the used card at the bottom of the same deck. 'Get Out of Jail Free' cards are held by the player until used.
original_text: Chance & Community Chest: Landing on these spaces shall trigger a card draw from the top of the respective shuffled deck, and its instructions shall be executed. Used cards are placed at the bottom of the deck.

formalized_text: The system shall correctly implement tax collection. Upon landing on 'Luxury Tax', the player must pay the fixed amount shown on the board. Upon landing on 'Income Tax', the human player must be presented with a choice to pay either a flat $200 or 10% of their total net worth. The system must correctly calculate total net worth as cash plus the printed value of all properties and the total cost of all buildings owned.
original_text: Tax Spaces: Players landing on Income Tax must choose to pay either a flat $200 or 10% of their total net worth. Total net worth is defined as cash on hand + the printed price of all owned properties + the purchase price of all buildings. Players landing on Luxury Tax must pay the fixed amount.

formalized_text: The system shall initialize each player's starting cash to $1500 at the beginning of a new game.
original_text: Each player shall start with $1500, distributed according to the official rules.

formalized_text: The system shall include a 'Bank' entity responsible for managing all economic transactions. The Bank will issue starting funds, collect payments for properties, taxes, and buildings, and handle all cash flows related to rent and mortgages. The Bank has an infinite supply of cash.
original_text: The Bank shall manage all monetary transactions, including initial funds, property purchases, rent payments, taxes, building costs, and mortgage transactions.

formalized_text: When the human player lands on an unowned property they can afford, the system must present a modal dialog with two choices: 'Buy' the property for its listed price, or decline and send the property to 'Auction'.
original_text: Purchase Decision: When a player lands on an unowned property: Human Player: A UI dialog shall be presented with options to 'Buy' the property for its list price or 'Auction' it.

formalized_text: The system shall implement an auction mechanism for unowned properties that a player declines to buy. The auction must start immediately, with bidding proceeding clockwise from the player who declined. The minimum bid is $1. All active players are eligible to bid. The property is awarded to the highest bidder, who pays their final bid amount to the Bank.
original_text: If a player declines to purchase, the property shall be immediately put up for auction. The auction starts with the player who declined the purchase. Bidding proceeds clockwise. The minimum starting bid is $1. Any player can bid, including the one who originally declined. The auction proceeds until no player is willing to increase the bid. The highest bidder pays the Bank and receives the property.

formalized_text: The system shall only permit a player to build houses or hotels on properties that are part of a complete color group owned entirely by that player (a monopoly).
original_text: Monopoly Requirement: A player may only build houses or hotels on properties belonging to a complete color set (a monopoly).

formalized_text: The system must strictly enforce the 'even building' rule. A player must build houses evenly across all properties of a single monopoly. A second house cannot be built on any property in a set until all properties in that set have one house. A hotel can only be built on a property after it has four houses, and only if all other properties in the set also have four houses.
original_text: Even Building Rule: The system shall enforce the even building rule. A player cannot build a second house on a property until all other properties in that color set have one house. This rule applies up to four houses per property. Hotels can only be built after four houses are on each property in the set.

formalized_text: The system shall manage a finite global supply of 32 houses and 12 hotels available from the Bank. If the supply of a building type is exhausted, players are prohibited from building more of that type. The user interface must provide clear feedback to the player when a building action is blocked due to a supply shortage.
original_text: Bank Supply: The game shall manage a finite supply of 32 houses and 12 hotels. If a player wishes to build but the supply is exhausted, they cannot do so until another player sells buildings back to the Bank. The UI must clearly communicate when a building shortage prevents construction.

formalized_text: The system shall handle building shortages via auction. If the number of available houses or hotels is less than the number players wish to buy, the available buildings must be auctioned off one by one to the highest bidder among the interested players. The auction shall start with the current player.
original_text: Building Shortages: If multiple players wish to buy the last available building(s), the buildings shall be sold via auction to the highest bidder, starting with the player whose turn it is.

formalized_text: The system shall allow a player to mortgage any of their properties that have no buildings on them. Upon mortgaging, the player shall receive the property's mortgage value in cash from the Bank. The system must prevent rent collection on any mortgaged property.
original_text: A player can mortgage any undeveloped property to the Bank to receive its mortgage value. No rent can be collected on mortgaged properties.

formalized_text: The system shall allow a player to unmortgage a property by paying the Bank its mortgage value plus a 10% interest fee. Upon payment, the property becomes active again for rent collection.
original_text: To unmortgage a property, the player must pay the Bank the mortgage value plus 10% interest.

formalized_text: The system shall facilitate trading between the human player and AI opponents. The human player must be able to initiate a trade with any AI at any time during their turn. When an AI proposes a trade to the human, a modal dialog must be displayed with options to 'Accept', 'Decline', or 'Propose Counter-Offer'.
original_text: The human player shall be able to initiate a trade with any AI opponent via a dedicated trading UI at any point during their turn. AI players can propose trades to the human player. A UI dialog shall be presented to the human player with options to 'Accept', 'Decline', or 'Propose Counter-Offer'.

formalized_text: The system's AI shall be capable of initiating, evaluating, and completing trades with other AI players. The logic for these trades must be influenced by the AI's difficulty setting. Any completed AI-to-AI trade must be communicated to the human player via a non-intrusive UI notification.
original_text: AI-to-AI Trades: AI shall be capable of proposing, evaluating, and responding to trade offers with other AI players based on its difficulty setting. These trades shall be announced to the human player via a non-intrusive UI notification.

formalized_text: The system shall provide at least three selectable difficulty levels for AI opponents, designated as 'Easy', 'Medium', and 'Hard'.
original_text: The game shall provide at least three distinct AI difficulty levels: Easy, Medium, and Hard.

formalized_text: The AI's decision-making process shall be driven by a set of configurable parameters that are tuned for each difficulty level. These parameters must govern behaviors such as property acquisition, building strategy, trading logic, mortgage management, and financial risk aversion.
original_text: The AI's behavior shall be controlled by a set of parameters tuned for each difficulty level, including: Property Purchase Threshold, Building Strategy, Trading Aggressiveness and Logic, Mortgage Management, Risk Aversion.

formalized_text: The system's AI shall be implemented using a Behavior Tree architecture. All tunable AI behavior parameters for the different difficulty levels must be stored in an external JSON configuration file that is loaded at runtime, allowing for adjustments without recompiling the application.
original_text: The AI's decision-making logic shall be implemented using a Behavior Tree architecture... AI behavior parameters for each difficulty level shall be stored in an external configuration file (JSON) to allow for tuning and balancing without requiring a full application rebuild.

formalized_text: The AI difficulty levels shall exhibit distinct strategic profiles: 'Easy' AI will make sub-optimal decisions, such as declining valuable properties and accepting poor trades. 'Medium' AI will play competently, prioritizing monopolies and making fair trades. 'Hard' AI will play strategically, aggressively pursuing monopolies, blocking opponents via trades, and attempting to create housing shortages.
original_text: Easy: AI will play sub-optimally... Medium: AI will play competently... Hard: AI will play strategically...

formalized_text: The system shall declare a player bankrupt if they owe a debt to the Bank or another player that they cannot pay, even after liquidating all their assets by selling all buildings and mortgaging all properties.
original_text: A player is declared bankrupt if they cannot cover a debt after selling all houses/hotels and mortgaging all properties.

formalized_text: When a player is bankrupted by another player (the creditor), the system must transfer all of the bankrupt player's assets—including remaining cash, all properties, and any 'Get Out of Jail Free' cards—to the creditor. Any properties that were mortgaged at the time of transfer shall remain mortgaged, requiring the new owner to pay the standard 10% interest to unmortgage them.
original_text: Debt to Another Player: If a player goes bankrupt to another player, the bankrupt player's entire portfolio (cash, properties, Get Out of Jail Free cards) is transferred to the creditor. Mortgaged properties remain mortgaged and the new owner must pay the 10% interest fee if they choose to unmortgage them later.

formalized_text: When a player is bankrupted by the Bank, the system must return all of their properties to the Bank. These properties must then be immediately auctioned off, one by one, to the remaining players in the game.
original_text: Debt to Bank: If a player goes bankrupt to the Bank, all their properties are returned to the Bank and immediately put up for auction, one by one, to the remaining players.

formalized_text: The system shall trigger a win condition for the human player when they are the last active player in the game, after all AI opponents have been declared bankrupt. Upon winning, a victory screen must be displayed.
original_text: Win Condition: The human player is the last remaining participant, with all AI opponents having gone bankrupt. The system shall display a victory screen.

formalized_text: The system shall trigger a lose condition if the human player is declared bankrupt. A game-over screen must be displayed to the player. Following this, the system must continue to simulate the remainder of the game between the AI opponents at high speed until a single AI winner is determined, at which point the final game summary is shown.
original_text: Lose Condition: The human player is declared bankrupt. The game shall display a game-over screen for the human player. The game will then continue to simulate the remaining AI players' turns at high speed until a single winner is determined to ensure accurate final game statistics are recorded.

formalized_text: The system shall display a game summary screen after the conclusion of a match (either by human win or determination of an AI winner). This screen must display key statistics from that match for all participating players, including their final net worth, properties owned, and total rent collected.
original_text: Game Summary Screen: Following either a win or lose condition, a detailed game summary screen shall be displayed, showing key statistics for all players from that specific match (e.g., final net worth, properties owned, total rent collected).

formalized_text: The system shall render a persistent Heads-Up Display (HUD) during gameplay. The HUD must display essential information for every player, including their name, token icon, and current cash total. It must also feature a clear visual indicator to show which player's turn it is.
original_text: The main game screen shall feature a persistent Heads-Up Display (HUD) showing at-a-glance information for all players, including name, token, cash, and a clear indicator for the current turn.

formalized_text: The system shall visually represent property ownership directly on the game board. Each owned property space must display a color-coded marker or border that corresponds to the token color of the owning player.
original_text: The game board shall visually indicate property ownership using color-coded markers or borders.

formalized_text: The system's UI shall use two distinct methods for presenting information: 1) Modal dialogs that halt gameplay must be used for critical human player decisions. 2) Non-intrusive, auto-dismissing notifications must be used for informational events that do not require player input.
original_text: The system shall use modal dialogs for critical, turn-halting player decisions (e.g., buying property, responding to a trade). The system shall use non-intrusive, temporary notifications for informational events (e.g., an AI-to-AI trade, another player paying rent).

formalized_text: The system shall provide a dedicated Property Management interface for the human player. This interface must be easily accessible during their turn and must provide the functionality to view owned properties, build/sell buildings, mortgage/unmortgage properties, and initiate trades.
original_text: The game shall provide a dedicated, easily accessible interface for the human player to view their properties, build houses/hotels, manage mortgages, and initiate trades.

formalized_text: The system shall present a Game Setup screen before a new game begins. This screen must provide UI controls for the human player to: 1) Enter their profile name, 2) Select their game token, 3) Choose the number of AI opponents, and 4) Set the difficulty level for each individual AI.
original_text: The system shall display a setup screen allowing the human player to enter a profile name, select a game piece, choose the number of AI opponents, and set the difficulty for each.

formalized_text: The system shall provide a two-panel trading interface. One panel shall display the human player's assets, and the other shall display the trade partner's assets. This interface must allow for the multi-selection of properties, cash, and 'Get Out of Jail Free' cards from both sides to construct a single, comprehensive trade offer.
original_text: The system shall implement a clear, two-panel trading interface for proposing and receiving trades, allowing for the selection and exchange of multiple properties, cash, and 'Get Out of Jail Free' cards in a single offer.

formalized_text: The system shall provide access to a settings menu from within an active game session (e.g., via a pause menu).
original_text: The game shall include a settings menu accessible during gameplay.

formalized_text: The settings menu shall include a 'Game Speed' option with at least three levels (e.g., Normal, Fast, Instant). This setting must control the duration of animations and the delay for AI thinking time. During an auction involving the human player, the game speed must be temporarily set to 'Normal' regardless of the user's setting, reverting back after the auction concludes.
original_text: This menu shall feature a 'Game Speed' setting (e.g., Normal, Fast, Instant) that controls animation durations and AI decision delays. The selected game speed shall be temporarily overridden and set to 'Normal' during any auction involving the human player.

formalized_text: The settings menu shall provide three independent volume control sliders: Master Volume, Music Volume, and Sound Effects (SFX) Volume.
original_text: The menu shall provide separate volume sliders for Master Volume, Music, and Sound Effects.

formalized_text: The settings menu shall contain data management options to 'Reset Statistics' and 'Delete Saved Games'. Both actions must trigger a confirmation dialog box before proceeding. If confirmed, the 'Reset' option will erase all historical player stats and high scores, while the 'Delete' option will erase all save game files.
original_text: The settings menu shall provide options for the user to: Reset all historical player statistics and high scores to their default state after a confirmation prompt. Delete all saved game files after a confirmation prompt.

formalized_text: The system shall include an optional, interactive tutorial. The tutorial must guide a new player through a scripted, step-by-step sequence covering the fundamental game actions, such as rolling dice, moving, buying property, and paying rent.
original_text: The game shall include an optional, interactive, step-by-step tutorial mode that guides new players through the basic rules and actions of a game.

formalized_text: The system shall provide a digital rulebook that is accessible from both the main menu and the in-game pause menu. This rulebook must include a search functionality to allow users to find specific rules quickly.
original_text: A searchable digital rulebook shall be accessible from the main menu and the in-game pause menu to allow players to look up specific rules.

formalized_text: The content for the digital rulebook must be loaded from an external, structured data file (e.g., JSON), not hardcoded into the application. This allows for rulebook text to be updated without recompiling the game.
original_text: The rulebook content shall be sourced from a structured data file (JSON) to facilitate easy updates.

formalized_text: The system shall be architected for localization readiness. All user-facing text, including UI elements, card text, and rulebook content, must be stored in external resource files (e.g., JSON) and loaded into the application using a key-based lookup system. No user-facing strings may be hardcoded. The initial release will ship with an English language file only.
original_text: Localization Readiness: All user-facing strings (UI text, card descriptions, rulebook content) shall be stored in external resource files (JSON) and referenced by a key, not hardcoded. The initial release will only include English, but the architecture must support future localization.

formalized_text: The system shall provide the functionality to save the current game state. This action shall be available to the human player at any point during their turn, but must be disabled after they have rolled the dice for that turn.
original_text: The system shall allow the game state to be saved at any point during the human player's turn (before the dice roll).

formalized_text: The system shall provide the user with a minimum of five distinct slots to save their game progress.
original_text: The system shall provide at least five save game slots.

formalized_text: The system shall serialize the `GameState` object into a versioned JSON format for saving, using the `System.Text.Json` library. All save files must be stored in a 'saves' subdirectory within the application's data folder at `%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon/`.
original_text: Save files shall use a versioned JSON format, serialized using the `System.Text.Json` library... Save files shall be stored in the user's local application data folder (`%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon/saves`).

formalized_text: The system must implement a checksum or hash validation mechanism for all save files. When displaying the list of saved games, the system must check the integrity and version compatibility of each file. Any file that is detected as corrupt or from an incompatible version must be clearly marked as 'unusable' or 'incompatible' in the UI.
original_text: The system shall implement checksums to detect file corruption. If a corrupted or incompatible (due to version mismatch) file is detected, it will be clearly marked as unusable in the load game menu.

formalized_text: The system shall store all player statistics and high scores in a local SQLite database file located at `%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon/`. Upon each successful application startup, the system must check if the database file has been modified since the last session. If it has, a backup of the file must be created. The system must automatically manage these backups, retaining only the three most recent copies.
original_text: Player statistics and high scores shall be stored in a local SQLite database file, also located in `%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon/`. On successful application startup, the system shall automatically create a backup of the player statistics SQLite database if it has changed since the last backup. The system shall retain the three most recent backups...

formalized_text: The system must include a data migration mechanism to handle older versions of save files and the statistics database. Upon detecting an older version file, the system shall attempt to automatically and atomically migrate it to the current version's format, preserving all user data. If migration fails, the original file must be left untouched.
original_text: The application must include logic to detect and handle older versions of save files and the statistics database. Where feasible, an automatic migration process shall be implemented to upgrade older data files to the current version upon first load, preserving user progress across game updates.

formalized_text: The system shall maintain and display a 'Top Scores' list of the top 10 victories by the human player. This data must be persisted in the SQLite database and sorted in descending order of final net worth. Each entry in the list must record the profile name, final net worth, game duration, and the total number of turns.
original_text: The game shall persist a list of the top 10 game victories achieved by the human player, read from the local SQLite database and sorted by final net worth descending. Each entry shall record the player's profile name, final net worth, game duration, and total turns.

formalized_text: The system shall provide a user-clickable button on the Top Scores screen to export the currently displayed high score list to a human-readable, formatted text (.txt) file.
original_text: The system shall provide a button to export the Top Score History to a local, human-readable text file (.txt).

formalized_text: The system shall be built with a theme system that allows for the dynamic replacement of visual and audio assets, including the game board model, player tokens, background music, and UI skin. The initial release must include at least two complete, distinct themes for the user to choose from.
original_text: The game shall support a theme system for dynamic replacement of visual and audio assets (e.g., board, tokens, music, UI skin). The game must ship with a minimum of two distinct themes (e.g., 'Classic' and 'Futuristic').

formalized_text: The system shall implement a comprehensive audio system. This includes: 1) Sound effects for key game actions (e.g., dice roll, purchase, jail). 2) Distinct audio cues to differentiate positive (e.g., receiving rent), negative (e.g., paying tax), and neutral events. 3) A context-aware background music system that changes tracks based on the game state (e.g., early game vs. late game).
original_text: The game shall incorporate sound effects for key actions... provide distinct audio cues for positive, negative, and neutral events... feature a context-aware background music system...

formalized_text: The system shall include a digital User Manual, accessible from the main menu, that documents software-specific features. The manual must cover topics including game setup, UI layout and navigation, how to use the save/load system, and an explanation of all available settings.
original_text: A digital User Manual shall be included and accessible from the main menu. This manual will cover software-specific features such as game setup, UI navigation, save/load functionality, and settings configuration.

formalized_text: A set of internal technical documentation shall be created and maintained alongside the source code. This documentation must include: 1) High-level system architecture diagrams, 2) Formal data schemas for the save file JSON and the statistics SQLite database, and 3) A detailed description of all configurable AI behavior parameters and their effects.
original_text: Internal technical documentation shall be maintained for development and support purposes, including: High-level system architecture diagrams. Data schemas for the JSON save file format and the SQLite statistics database. Documentation of the configurable AI behavior parameters.

formalized_text: The system shall perform a non-blocking check for application updates upon startup. If a newer version is detected, a non-intrusive notification shall be displayed to the user, providing a hyperlink to the official download page. The application must not download or install updates automatically.
original_text: The application shall include a non-intrusive mechanism to check for new versions upon startup. If an update is available, it will notify the user and provide a link to the project's download page. The application will not perform automatic updates.

formalized_text: The system shall include a Data Privacy statement, accessible from the main menu. The text of this statement must explicitly declare that the application functions offline and does not collect or transmit any user data, PII, or gameplay telemetry to any remote server.
original_text: A formal data privacy statement shall be accessible from the main menu. The statement shall clarify that the application operates entirely offline and does not collect, store, or transmit any personally identifiable information (PII) or gameplay telemetry to any external server.

formalized_text: The system must ensure that all implemented game assets, including names, designs, and text, strictly conform to the intellectual property and branding guidelines as specified in the licensing agreement with Hasbro, Inc.
original_text: All game assets, including but not limited to the "Monopoly" brand name, board design, property names, card text, and token designs, must strictly adhere to the terms of the licensing agreement with Hasbro, Inc.

formalized_text: The system's uninstaller must perform a clean removal of all application files and associated registry entries. During the uninstallation process, the user must be presented with an explicit choice to either keep or delete their personal data located in the `%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon/` directory.
original_text: The installer must provide a clean uninstallation process that removes all application files and registry entries, with the explicit option for the user to retain or delete their personal data (save files, profiles).
